natural problem:
What real values of $x$ are not in the domain of

$f(x)=\frac{1}{|x^2+3x-4|+|x^2+9x+20|}$?
natural solution: $x$ is not in the domain of $f$ if the denominator is zero. Since both absolute values are nonnegative, both must be zero for the denominator to be zero.

So \begin{align} 0=x^2+3x-4=(x+4)(x-1)&\Rightarrow x=-4\text{ or }x=1\\ 0=x^2+9x+20=(x+4)(x+5)&\Rightarrow x=-4\text{ or }x=-5 \end{align} The only value of $x$ which makes both absolute values zero is $x=\boxed{-4}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = 1 / (abs (x powr 2 + 3 * x - 4) + abs (x powr 2 + 9 * x + 20))"
shows  "x \<noteq> -4"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What real values of $x$ are not in the domain of

$f(x)=\frac{1}{|x^2+3x-4|+|x^2+9x+20|}$? The final Answer is -4
 ### Proof
 $x$ is not in the domain of $f$ if the denominator is zero. Since both absolute values are nonnegative, both must be zero for the denominator to be zero.
 So \begin{align} 0=x^2+3x-4=(x+4)(x-1)&\Rightarrow x=-4\text{ or }x=1\\ 0=x^2+9x+20=(x+4)(x+5)&\Rightarrow x=-4\text{ or }x=-5 \end{align} The only value of $x$ which makes both absolute values zero is $x=\boxed{-4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = 1 / (abs (x powr 2 + 3 * x - 4) + abs (x powr 2 + 9 * x + 20))"
shows  "x \<noteq> -4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = 1 / (abs (x^2 + 3 * x - 4) + abs (x^2 + 9 * x + 20))"
and h1 : "f x undefined"
shows  "x = -4"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What real values of $x$ are not in the domain of

$f(x)=\frac{1}{|x^2+3x-4|+|x^2+9x+20|}$? The final Answer is -4
 ### Proof
 $x$ is not in the domain of $f$ if the denominator is zero. Since both absolute values are nonnegative, both must be zero for the denominator to be zero.
 So \begin{align} 0=x^2+3x-4=(x+4)(x-1)&\Rightarrow x=-4\text{ or }x=1\\ 0=x^2+9x+20=(x+4)(x+5)&\Rightarrow x=-4\text{ or }x=-5 \end{align} The only value of $x$ which makes both absolute values zero is $x=\boxed{-4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = 1 / (abs (x^2 + 3 * x - 4) + abs (x^2 + 9 * x + 20))"
and h1 : "f x undefined"
shows  "x = -4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: For the function $f(x) = \frac{1}{|x^2 + 3x - 4| + |x^2 + 9x + 20|}$, find the value of $x$ for which $f(x)$ is undefined. The final answer is $x = -4$.
